description:
Awesome to see VSCode being packaged as this.

For those who are puzzled to not have anything but `sh` in the terminal: Install the relevant Flatpak SDKs (i.e. `org.freedesktop.Sdk.Extension.node10`)!

Other users are reporting that VS Code is licensed under the MIT license, this is partially true. The source code is licensed under MIT, however, the binary distributed by Microsoft is not. Microsoft includes proprietary components that are not found on the GitHub repository where they publish.

There are reviews saying this is MIT licensed, not technically correct, as this flatpak includes proprietary components, such as logos and telemetry (disabled by default I believe), which makes it proprietary. The actual editor source code is MIT licensed though.

That being said, great text editor with lots of IDE features, runs great. Integrated terminal is a bit awkward to use in the flatpak version though. You can run tools from the host system but you have to preface it with flatpak spawn --host. Useful in my case on Silverblue because I can flatpak spawn --host toolbox enter and be off to the races with a Fedora 30 environment.
A super code editor.
It is a great editor and it's incredibly hackable. You can run you code on a remote machine and even on WSL. It's great!

Works great, you can easily configurate terminal and other plugins to use scripts from outside. I run scripts from fedora toolbox.

While the source code this app is build on is open source. When microsoft builds the binary it is released with their proprietary license. Despite the source code being released open source the copyright holder (Microsoft) has the right to take that source code, make any changes they see fit, build a binary, and release it under a non-opensource license which is what has happened with VSCode.
Light weight yet powerfull

To the people here thinking that this is free software: The binary you download from the official website (or from Flathub, in this case) is NOT built from the MIT licensed source. It's a proprietary build with telemetry and other non-free components added. See the disclaimer at the top here [1]


[1] https://code.visualstudio.com/License/

View > Integrated Terminal or Ctrl + ` opens up an integrated terminal. If anyone has an issue with linking a javascript or css file to an html file, then don't worry, for there is an easy solution. First, you have to open your konsole by searching through all your apps. In the konsole, if you don't have a password set up, then set it up by typing 
passwd
Once the password is set up, then all you have to do is copy and paste this line of code into the konsole.
sudo flatpak override com.visualstudio.code --filesystem=home
and then type in your password. Then, you'll be able to code with html, javascript, and css just like the original.

description:
L'application fonctionne sans problème avec toutes ses fonctionnalités.

Seul bémol (mais pas pour moi), l'isolation fournit par Flatpak empêche VSCode d'avoir accès aux compilateurs/interpréteurs de votre système.

En clair si vous avez par exemple Java installé sur votre système, VSCode ne peut pas y avoir accès (car isolé de votre système), et ainsi il ne peut compiler/exécuter votre code.
Vous devez donc le faire manuellement (via une commande custom), ou alors installer le RPM.

Notez que les compilateur C/C++, Go, ainsi que l'interpréteur Python sont installé par défaut avec VSCode dans son conteneur !

VSCode est un excellent éditeur de code, mais on pourrait croire que la version Flatpak est au rabais en comparaison d'un paquet plus traditonnel. Ce n'est pas le cas. 

Avec le flatpak com.visualstudio.code.tool.podman, et Podman+Distrobox (ou Toolbox) d'installés, il ne vous suffit plus qu'à installer l'extension Dev Container pour pouvoir développer dans un environnement tout propre avec tout les paquets que l'on peut demander.

Pour plus de renseignement, tapez "VSCode Flatpak" dans la barre de recherche de votre navigateur, vous trouverez sans doute des articles interessants !
